III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 7/14/23 youth was brought to the hospital due to an allergic
reaction to a bee sting. While there, youth was also flagged as a
high suicide risk and was expected to complete an evaluation with
a social worker. Youth was being kept under observation after
being administered epinephrine and was on suicide watch. Youth
became agitated and requested to leave. Staff agreed to let youth
leave against medical advice and without a safety plan. Youth was
not monitored the full recommended time after an allergic reaction.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant/Hospital Social Worker was interviewed via
video conference on 7/24/23 in conjunction with MDHHS
Worker. Complainant reported she did not meet or have any
interactions with Youth A and Staff 1 on 7/14/23. Complainant
reported she received the allegations second-hand from the
medical team treating Youth A. Complainant stated the medical
team reported concerns Youth A left with Staff 1. However,
Complainant reported the team’s biggest concern was Youth A left
without Complainant being able to complete the suicide
assessment, which was required based on Youth A’s suicide
intake rating tool completed upon admission to the emergency
room.
Hospital Nurse was interviewed via phone on 8/14/23 in
conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Hospital Nurse reported she
worked directly with Youth A at the hospital on 7/14/23. Hospital
Nurse reported Youth A came into the emergency room due to a
bee sting she had received and an Epi-pen she administered on
herself. Before Staff 1 came into the emergency room, Hospital
Nurse completed the suicide intake tool for Youth A and Youth A
flagged high risk due to her history, not due to current suicidal
ideations. Hospital Nurse had a hospital sitter sit outside of Youth
A’s room as that is standard protocol for patients with suicide risk.
Hospital Nurse reported she then went to speak to the doctor to
determine if there was a need to get a hospital social worker
2

involved. Hospital Nurse reported there was not a decision made
during the conversation with the doctor. Hospital Nurse reported
she should have entered an order into the computer system to flag
a social worker to complete a suicide assessment based on the
rating tool completed. However, since the doctor did not decide
whether social work should be involved, Hospital Nurse forgot to
enter the order. Since the order was not entered, a suicide
assessment request was never officially requested or completed,
so no one spoke to Staff 1 about the requirement for an
assessment prior to Youth A leaving the hospital. Hospital Nurse
reported Youth A was irritated and anxious and did not want to
stay in the hospital for the two-hour monitoring period. Hospital
Nurse reported Staff 1 was sitting in the room, was not saying
anything to Youth A and was just allowing Youth A to become
more agitated while sitting in the room. When Hospital Nurse was
out of Youth A’s room, she received a message from the hospital
sitter stating Youth A and Staff 1 were walking out of the room and
leaving the hospital. Hospital Nurse reported she stopped Youth A
and Staff 1 and explained Youth A’s care was not done because
they needed to monitor her for a certain amount of time to ensure
she did not have any reactions from the bee sting or Epi-pen
administration. Hospital Nurse reported Youth A was very anxious
and did not want to stay anymore, so Hospital Nurse told Staff 1
she needed to get the doctor to discharge Youth A before they
left. Hospital Nurse reported Staff 1 and Youth A sat in the waiting
room. Hospital Nurse stated she spoke with the doctor, and they
both felt comfortable discharging Youth A because she was
almost there for the required two hours. Hospital Nurse reported
Youth A was not on a behavioral health hold and was not required
to complete a suicide assessment prior to leaving because an
order for the assessment was never completed. Hospital Nurse
reported the doctor was comfortable with Youth A being
discharged, which is why the discharge paperwork was completed
and did not state it was a discharge against medical advice.
Hospital Nurse reported she was not aware a complaint was being
made or MDHHS would be involved because there were not
concerns with Youth A leaving.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 7/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported on
7/14/23, she was stung by a bee while she and other youth were
with facility staff at a local park. Youth A reported she is allergic to
bees and when she gets stung, it’s hard to breathe. Youth A
reported when she gets stung, she uses an Epi-pen and can
administer it herself. Then she is supposed to ask staff to call 911
or she will call 911 and notify staff if she is not present with staff.
3

Youth A reported she then must go to the hospital, and they must
monitor her for two hours. Youth A reported she has gotten stung
by a bee an unknown number of times since being at the facility,
although not all the bee stings have occurred on the facility’s
campus. After the bee sting on 7/14/23, Youth A reported she
administered her Epi-pen, Staff 2 called 911 and then an
ambulance took Youth A to the hospital. Youth A reported on
7/14/23, she did not want to be in the hospital because she was
stressed. Youth A reported she was feeling really depressed and
all the cords in the hospital room were making her want to hang
herself. Youth A reported she asked to speak to the doctor twice
because she wanted to be discharged, but the doctor did not
come talk to her. Youth A reported she told Hospital Nurse and
other hospital staff she wanted to leave and wanted to speak to
the doctor. Youth A reported Staff 1 was sitting in the hospital
room with her, and she told Staff 1 how she was feeling. Staff 1
agreed to try and get the doctor into the room. Youth A reported
after she told Staff 1 how she was feeling, Youth A pulled out her
IV, got dressed and started walking out of the room. When Youth
A started getting dressed, Youth A said Staff 1 tried to get her to
stay and said, “please don’t do this; it’s not worth it”. Youth A
reported she didn’t want to be there, so she didn’t listen to Staff 1.
Youth A reported they walked into the lobby and Hospital Nurse
came out to talk to them. Youth A reported Hospital Nurse said,
“we are going to have to make a complaint because it’s child
neglect to leave the hospital before she’s fully discharged”. Youth
A reported she did not remember what Staff 1 did or said when
Hospital Nurse gave that information. Hospital Nurse went back
into the hospital and when she came back out, Staff 1 and Youth
A went back to the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 7/18/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported she was
not present on 7/14/23 when Youth A got stung by the bee but
was asked to go to the hospital to sit with her. Staff 1 reported she
went to the park and followed the ambulance to the hospital. Upon
arriving to the hospital, Staff 1 reported she went into the room
with Youth A and there were medical staff talking to Youth A. The
medical staff stated they were going to give Youth A an IV,
Benadryl, steroids, and another medication (Staff 1 couldn’t
remember), and then they were going to monitor her for two
hours. Hospital Nurse told Staff 1 and Youth A there was going to
be a hospital sitter sitting outside of the room as a precaution due
to Youth A’s suicidal history. After a while, Youth A told Staff 1 she
couldn’t sit in the room for much longer because sitting in the
room for so long with nothing to do is what leads to her suicidal
4

thoughts. Hospital Nurse came in and checked on Youth A, and
Youth A asked to speak to the doctor because she wanted to
leave. Staff 1 reported Hospital Nurse stated the doctor was busy,
stated they would give him the message, but Youth A refused, so
the nurses told Youth A she only needed to be there for two hours
and didn’t have much time left. Shortly after Hospital Nurse left,
Staff 1 reported Youth A was sitting on her bed taking her IV out of
her arm. Staff 1 asked what Youth A what was she doing, and
Youth A reported she was removing the cords because she
wanted to leave because her suicidal thoughts were increasing
from sitting in the room doing nothing with all the cords around.
Youth A proceeded to put her shoes and shirt on and walk out of
the room. Staff 1 reported she felt she couldn’t physically force
Youth A to stay, so her priority was to follow Youth A to ensure her
safety, because that’s what they’re taught when youth at the
facility go AWOL. Staff 1 reported as she was following Youth A,
she asked Youth A to sit down in the waiting room and wait so she
could call Supervisor. Staff 1 reported she and Youth A both
talked to Supervisor. As Staff 1 was on the phone with Supervisor,
Hospital Nurse came up to them and asked if they were leaving, to
which Staff 1 replied “yes, if she wants to leave, I cannot stop her”.
Staff 1 reported Hospital Nurse said, “you’ll have to sign
something because Youth A’s not discharged yet”. Staff 1 got
back on the phone with Supervisor and updated her regarding
what Hospital Nurse said. Supervisor told Staff 1 she would call
her back after talking to Administrator. Supervisor called back a
couple minutes later and told Staff 1 she couldn’t get a hold of
Administrator but instructed Staff 1 not to sign anything. Then
Hospital Nurse came out with discharge paperwork and did not
ask her to sign anything. Staff 1 reported Hospital Nurse told Staff
1 to keep an eye on Youth A and if anything changes with Youth
A's breathing, bring her right back in. Staff 1 reported Hospital
Nurse never said she was going to make a complaint and did not
report any concerns with Youth A and Staff 1 leaving when she
brought the discharge paperwork to them. Staff 1 reported none of
the hospital staff ever talked to her about Youth A receiving a high
score on the suicidal screening tool or that a suicidal assessment
was required. Staff 1 reported the only thing she feels she could
have done better or differently in the situation was using more de-
escalation tools to ease Youth A’s anxiety or take Youth A’s mind
off things sooner, but she felt she didn’t have time to do it.
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
7/18/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Administrator
reported he was called by Supervisor after Youth A had pulled out
her IV, was attempting to leave the hospital and the hospital staff
5

had asked Staff 1 to sign paperwork. Administrator reported he
told Supervisor, Staff 1 was not allowed to sign medical release
forms because staff are not medically trained to assess what is
happening or what should happen. Administrator reported
Supervisor told him Staff 1 did not sign anything and they were
just in the entryway of the hospital waiting for discharge
paperwork. Administrator called Supervisor approximately ten
minutes later and Supervisor reported Staff 1 and Youth A were
heading back to the facility. Administrator reported today (7/18/23)
he received a call from the Hospital Clinical Supervisor regarding
her concerns with the situation. Hospital Clinical Supervisor told
Administrator she did not like the interactions Hospital Nurse had
with Staff 1, but reported she was only relaying second-hand
information from other hospital staff and was not present for the
interaction. Hospital Clinical Supervisor told Administrator, Staff 1
was dismissive to Youth A’s care and she feels Staff 1 could have
done more to be supportive of the medical team’s
opinion/direction and redirect Youth A to convince her to stay.
Supervisor was interviewed via phone on 7/24/23 in
conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor reported Staff 2
was with three youth at a local park. Staff 2 called Supervisor and
said Youth A was stung by a bee and someone needed to meet
her at the hospital. Supervisor said Staff 1 was assigned to go to
the hospital and sit with Youth A. Approximately two hours after
Youth A and Staff 1 were at the hospital, Staff 1 reached out to
Supervisor and stated Youth A took out her IV and was walking
out of the hospital. Staff 1 told Supervisor someone from the
hospital was trying to get her to sign something approving Youth A
to leave the hospital against medical advice. Supervisor stated
she told Staff 1 not to sign anything and she would call
Administrator for further direction. Supervisor reported she talked
to Youth A on the phone after she spoke with Staff 1. Supervisor
reported she tried to process Youth A's reasons for wanting to
leave the hospital and tried to convince her to stay. Youth A told
Supervisor when she was stuck in the hospital room with nothing
to keep her busy, she began having suicidal ideations and she
was adamant she was not going to stay at the hospital. Supervisor
stated she tried to help Youth A understand why the hospital was
asking them to stay and the importance of them monitoring her,
but Youth A made it clear she was not going to stay at the
hospital, and she felt fine. Supervisor reported after her
conversation with Youth A, she attempted to call Administrator,
but she had to leave a voicemail. Supervisor reported she then
called Staff 1 back to update her and Staff 1 told Supervisor the
hospital was discharging Youth A instead of having them sign
6

something. Supervisor reported she had no knowledge of Youth A
scoring high for suicide risk at the hospital because Staff 1 did not
tell her that information and it wasn’t mentioned on any of the
hospital discharge paperwork. Supervisor reported Youth A was
already on suicide precautions at the facility and those
precautions were already being followed.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• D.A. Blodgett St. John’s Epi Pen Administration Procedure
Policy outlines how to administer an Epi Pen and instructs
staff to call 911 immediately after administration.
• D.A. Blodgett St. John’s Medical Procedures Policy outlines
how youth are provided with services to address ongoing
medical, dental and vision care needs while at the facility.
• Incident Report for Youth A dated 7/14/23 notes Youth A
was on the swing at the local park and seemed lethargic.
Staff 2 spoke to Youth A and asked if she was okay. Youth
A reported she couldn’t breathe. Staff 2 gave Youth A her
inhaler. Youth A then touched her right leg and realized she
had been stung by a bee. Staff 2 took out Youth A’s Epi-
Pen and Youth A administered it. Youth A reported she did
not want to go to the hospital, but Staff 2 told her she had
to. Staff 2 contacted 911, who arrived and transported
Youth A to the hospital.
• Emergency Room Provider Notes for Youth A dated
7/14/23 completed by Doctor. Under section titled “Medical
Decision Making” it notes what medications and treatment
Youth A was provided with at the hospital. It also states
“Youth A was requesting to go home prior to the end of the
2-hour observation. She did walk out of the emergency
department to the waiting room with staff from D.A.
Blodgett. She did score high risk for suicide but denied
having suicidal thoughts during interview. Discharged home
with prescription for Prednisone for the next 3 days. Return
parameters explained to the patient at the time of discharge
by the nursing staff.” It notes Youth A arrived at 19:23 (7:23
pm) and was discharged at 21:06 (9:06 pm).
• After Visit Summary for Youth A dated 7/14/23 outlines
medications and treatment Youth A received in the
emergency room. Notes general follow-up information for
behavioral health and suicide crisis referrals as well as
7

emergency room virtual follow-up if needed. Also notes
how to care for a child after Anaphylaxis.
• Hospital Nurse’s emergency room note regarding Youth A
dated 7/14/23 was consistent with Hospital Nurse’s
interview and does not note any concerns.
• Complainant/Hospital Social Worker’s note regarding Youth
A dated 7/14/23 notes she completed a complaint for
medical neglect on the part of the D.A. Blodgett Staff
member. Complainant notes “D.A. Blodgett Staff was
aware patient flagged as high suicide risk and required
further medical monitoring following an allergic reaction.
There is concern about D.A. Blodgett staff appearing
flippant about the child’s medical and safety needs.”
• Staff 1 does not have any disciplinary actions in her
employee file. Staff 1 received training on Policies,
Procedures, Forms & More (which includes medical
policies) on 12/3/22.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. The Complainant/Hospital Social
Worker had no interactions with Youth A or Staff 1, and made a
complaint based on second-hand information. Hospital Nurse
consistently interacted with Youth A and Staff 1 while at the
hospital. Hospital Nurse reported there were no concerns with
Youth A being discharged and clarified Youth A was not
discharged against medical advice. Hospital Nurse also clarified
the reason a suicide assessment was not conducted on Youth A
at the hospital was because Hospital Nurse never put the order in,
not because Youth A and Staff 1 left the hospital.
CONSULTATION:
• Facility staff need to ensure they’re partnering with staff at the
hospital including the nurses, doctor, security & safety assistant
to ensure youth safety.
• If a youth is in the hospital and feeling anxious or a desire to
leave, facility staff should let hospital staff know the youth's angst
about being in the hospital so long. Emergency Room Clinical
Supervisor reported the hospital has distraction activities at the
hospital that can be utilized.
• If a youth is in the hospital and trying to leave against medical
advice, facility staff should tell hospital staff "I need help to keep
this child here" & security/hospital staff can assist keeping them
there to receive the appropriate treatment.
8

• Helen DeVos Children’s Hospital completes a suicide screening
tool for anyone over age 12 who comes into the emergency
room. Facility staff should check with assigned nurse to
determine what level of risk the youth scored at and the
expectations for assessments, etc. surrounding that risk level.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings, the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. However, based on the findings of SIR 2023C0000595,
it is recommended that the current First Provisional License for the facility be
continued.
